answers.answer: Hi,I think you have Lyme Disease. Check symptoms for this disease, yours are among many other symptoms for this ilness. Stiff neck, swollen and painful wrists, knees, elbows, etc...Your eyes are already attacked by Lyme bacterias(there are more then just one kind),as well as digestive and urinary tract.Your lab results are ok.Yes, it is typical for Lyme...seemingly everything is fine but your body tells you something different.You HAVE TO learn as much as you can for yourself about that disease. Dont rely on doctors in this case,start doing research and quickly you will find out why...Well, good news are-you can get better:)E.

Thank you so much for responding. You just don't understand(well maybe you do) how frustrating this is for me. I'm only 25 and have been dealing with this for a while. Is it possible to have lyme disease for 5 years? I have been in tears in doctors office and on many medications. I will look into this. Thank you soooo much.

You should definitely be checked for Lyme.  Also, some diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and Lupus can take a few years before your bloodwork shows positive.  It is important for you to keep on getting tested every few months.

Thanks! i am getting tested for lyme today. It's sad to say, but i want to have some type of curable disease. At least i will know what it is and then i can get treatment. i just wish i could wake up with no pain and run freely. I don't want to have pain throughout my 20's!!

Hi,You should know that most chronicly sick patients (like you) with Lyme will be tested negative for Borellia(Lyme).This bacteria is so aggressive that kills all antibodies very quickly, so the test will not detect anything.Good specialist knows that.Diagnosis will be based mostly on your symptoms.I've been having Lyme for over 3 years.I was tested 3 weeks after I found a tick on my arm-result negative.I really did not need this test to know that I had Lyme.I already had a rash, plus other Lyme symptoms.Test only proved how aggressive is that bacteria.If I were you, I would learn as much as I can about this disease, and find Lyme Disease specialist, not a regular doctor.There are many treatments, including natural ones.There are people who were confined to beds, and they started to walk, but it takes a lot of effort and discipline.
Hi agnes66400,how did you get lyme? how did you know you had it? are you getting better? is it possible to have it for 7 years and get better?

Hi,Sorry,I was away for the weekend, I couldn't answer earlier.Over 3 yrs ago I myself found a deer tick on my arm, I removed it, and after3 days I noticed a thick red erythema in the place where the tick was.Thatalarmed me,I started to search Internet looking for answers.I easily foundones.I was terrified, mostly because I knew that it was hard to find the rightdoctor.Official treatment for this disease is 2-3 weeks of antibiotictherapy.It is a very big lie.Of course behind that is money.Very quickly I learnedthat this disease is very difficult to treat.And requires a long termantibiotic therapy with high dosages of antibiotics.So, desperately I begun to lookfor a Lyme specialist, who would give me prescription for antibiotics.I foundone, exspensive, but at least I had right treatment.I was on Doxycycline400md/day, plus Cefuroxime1000md/day for 6 months.Then I stared herbal treatment.Istarted treatment one weeks after tick bite.According to all books I shouldbe cured, I am not, but I am better.It is so much more you should know aboutit.Still,I consider myself lucky, because I had that rash after the bite,which alarmed me.Only about 30% of infected people have rash.If not that I wouldbe thinking why I have knee, ankle pain, why my neck is stiff, why my handsare numb, and many many other symptoms.I was reading a lot of stories about people whe were already sick for 10yers, they were misdiagnosed with multiply sclerosis.I remember a guy who wasdiagnosed with MS, he was incontinent of urine,disease was progressing.But oneday he found out about LYme.He started to take high dosages of ABT's,after 8months he became continent, and many other symptomps started to disapear, butfor such cases it takes years to get better, but yes, it is possible.You will get better too,  if you start the right treatment.You can write onmy email if you have any questions, there is so much more you should know.Itis not possible for me to write it here.***@****
I had a lyme disease test and all 10 strands were negative. Back to square one. My feet are burning and it feels like it's going up my legs.

Hi curleegirl,Constipation and stomach bloating can be symptoms of Celiac disease (an intolerance to gluten).  Because celiac is an autoimmune condition, it could also account for the inflammation (the ESR and C-Reactive Protein). I'm not sure if this is what's causing your problem, but you can ask for a celiac blood panel (there are several tests they can run -- may sure you're getting them all).  The classic symptoms of Celiac are things like stomach pain, gas, bloating, constipation or diarrhea, but really the symptoms can be all over the map, and include things like joint pain, sore throat, neurological symptoms, fatigue, anxiety, mood changes/depression.  (I had a bunch of different symptoms, including extreme heat and exercise intolerance -- red feet and hands, bulging veins ...)  Untreated celiac increases the chance of developing other conditions (like RA, thyroid disease, and lymphoma), so it's a good thing to diagnose early (or rule out).Frequent urination and vision problems can be signs/symptoms of diabetes (type 1 diabetes is autoimmune, and can co-occur with Celiac).  I don't know much about diabetes, and it looks like they checked your glucose, but you could see an endocrinologistYour primary care doctor should be able to order the Celiac test, but I agree with agnes that you should keep an eye on the autoimmune diseases -- based on your symptoms, I would try to see a gastroenterologist and a rheumatologist.  And I think you could keep the lyme in mind.  Before my celiac diagnosis, I was tested for Lyme, it came back negative, but my neurologist gave me a month's course of antibiotics just to be on the safe side (I'm a hiker).Finally, another thing you could do (if you haven't already) is go into a big bookstore and browse through books on autoimmune disease and women's health (e.g., The Autoimmune Epidemic by Faust and Buyon, or other books that offer checklists of possible symptoms).  Your ANA was negative, so maybe it's not autoimmune, but so many women I know have autoimmune problems ...Anyway, sorry for the long post, but I know how frustrating this can be.  I hope you find some answers soon.tcgps - Be aggressive and do what you need to do to get a diagnosis. If doctors dismiss your concerns, go to someone else.  I saw 9 different doctors in 6 months before getting a diagnosis.  I found *How Doctors Think* to be a helpful book for communicating with doctors more effectively.
Oops -- I see your profile lists you as male.  But that doesn't change my advice, really.  I have at least 4 guy friends with autoimmune diseases (crohn's, diabetes, and 2  w/ celiac).

You might check this out:http://ibdcrohns.about.com/cs/relatedconditions/a/arthritisibd.htmAlso this (in light of your parvovirus test):"In fact, clinical, pathological, and virological data suggest an active role for B19 virus infection in the development and evolution of inflammatory bowel disease in a genetically predisposed host. Infective disorders of the gastrointestinal tract may have histological features that mimic Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis (11) or that can be associated with intestinal villous atrophy, with or without increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, which may require a differential diagnosis of a refractory celiac disease (3)."http://jcm.asm.org/cgi/content/full/47/5/1591?maxtoshow=&HITS=10&hits=10&RESULTFORMAT=&fulltext=hybridization&searchid=1&FIRSTINDEX=1540&resourcetype=HWFIG

question: I am in desperate need of health help!! I am a young and active person. I run marathons, dance, and cheer for an NFL team.I have been been going to the doctor for about 12 months now and no one can seem to figure out what is wrong with me. I have the following symptoms for about 4 years and they are increasingly getting worse.Symptoms:- swollen connective tissue in- elbows,right knee, and writs- neck is stiff and can not turn to the right- constipation- stomach bloating- left ankle swollen on left side- right ankle swollen on right side- right foot sore to touch at top- right leg sore to touch along shin- elbows hurt when i extend arm completely- vision is becoming blurry- increased urinating at nightTest I've taken that all came back neg:- CREATININE UR PERIOD- CREATININE UR TIMED VOLUME- CREATININE UR CONC- PROTEIN UR PERIOD- PROTEIN TOTAL VOLUME- PROTEIN UR CONC- CREATININE UR CONC- HLA B27- LDH- HEP C AB- HEP B CORE AB- ANGIOTENSIN CONV ENZYME- PARVOVIRUS B19 AB IGM- RHEUMATOID FACTOR- SMITH AB- SM RNP AB- SJOGREN'S SCRN, QUAL.- INTERPRETATION ANA- URC SPECIMEN DESCRIPTION- URC SPECIAL REQUESTS- URC CULTURE- URC REPORT STATUS- UA WBC HPF- UA RBC HPF- UA EPTH CELLS HPF- UA BACTERIA- UA MUCOUS- UA SPECIFIC GRAVITY- UA PH- UA LEUKOCYTES- UA NITRITE- UA UROBILINOGEN- UA GLUCOSE- UA BILIRUBIN- UA BLOOD- CCP AB IGG- HIV- TSH- ANA SCREENI was flagged on the following test:- NEUTROPHIL ABS 45- EOSINOPHIL % 8- NEUTROPHIL % 45- WBC 3.8- URIC ACID 2.3- KETONES UR 1+- UA PROTEIN 1+- ESR 27- C-REACTIVE PROTEIN INFLAMMATORY 16.9- PARVOVIRUS B19 AB IGG- PROTEIN UR TIMED 162- CREATININE UR TIMED 1817Has anyone seen anything similar to this or felt like me?
title: If I don't have arthritis, what do i have??? help
